I.  THE ENSUING PROGRAM 
 
1.   The government of Georgia has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide 
support by lending for the proposed Georgia State Electrosystem (GSE) Corporatization and 
Electricity Market Reforms Program. 
 
2.  The  proposed  program  aims  to  strengthen  the  corporate  governance  and  financial 
management of GSE (Georgia’s electricity transmission company), and improve electricity market 
competition  by  supporting  an  independent  market  operator.  These  reforms  are  critical  to 
strengthen  GSE’s  corporate  governance,  financial  management,  transparency  and  debt 
sustainability; and to improve electricity market competition. The proposed policy-based loan will 
be implemented during 2018–2019. The indicative loan amount for the program loan is $50 million 
from ordinary capital resources (regular). 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help the government design and develop 
the  capacity  to  implement  the  reform  program,  and  undertake  program  coordination  with 
stakeholders. The transaction TA is needed on the following grounds:1  
(i)  program due diligence requires external expertise;  
(ii)  although the government is committed to implementing reforms, there is a need to 
build stakeholders’ implementation capacity; 
(iii)  external  expertise  is  needed  to  develop  and  support  implementation  of  the 
corporate governance plan and debt management strategy; and  
(iv)  to support donor coordination and stakeholder consultation.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
5.  The TA is estimated to cost $0.85 million, of which $0.70 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The TA proceeds shall be 
disbursed in accordance with the ADB Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time).  The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 1.          
 
6.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, data and information, 
and other in-kind contributions. The value of the government’s in-kind contribution is estimated at 
$0.15 million. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
7.  ADB will administer the TA. The Energy Division of the Central and West Asia Department, 
in consultation with the executing agency, will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants.
